Although we focus on work/public spaces such as offices and shopping areas, the effectiveness of UV-C light may require additional considerations in schools and other environments where social distancing is more difficult to maintain. In particular, prevaccination-era studies showed that UV light could reduce spreading of viruses such as measles, chickenpox, and mumps among school children
64 but with an effectiveness that was very dependent on the afterschool environment ( e.g., crowded accommodations and public transport).
93 UV-C light can also be kept in place for the long-term, as it should help reduce infections by pathogens, but should not preclude children from entering into contact with those microorganisms that are thought to be important in the development of the immune system (the so-called hygiene hypothesis
94 ).
